As an example, [[Bart Ehrman]] states that gnostic writings of the [[Gospel of Thomas]] (part of the Nag Hammadi library) have very little value in historical Jesus research, because the author of that gospel placed no importance on the physical experiences of Jesus (e.g. his crucifixion) or the physical existence of believers, and was only interested in the secret teachings of Jesus rather than any physical events.<ref name=BartProphet72 /> Similarly, the [[Apocryphon of John]] (also part of the Nag Hammadi library) has been useful in studying the prevailing attitudes in the second century, and questions of authorship regarding the [[Book of revelation]], given that it refers to [[s:Bible (American Standard)/Revelation#1|Revelation 1:19]], but is mostly about the [[Ascension of Jesus|post ascension]] teachings of Jesus in a vision, not a narrative of his life.<ref>''The Book of Revelation'' by [[Robert H. Mounce]] 1997 {{ISBN|0802825370}} p. 11</ref> Some scholars such as Edward Arnal contend that the Gospel of Thomas continues to remain useful for understanding how the teachings of Jesus were transmitted among early Christians, and sheds light on the development of early Christianity.<ref>''The Symbolic Jesus'' by William Edward Arnal 2005 {{ISBN|1845530071}} pp. 60–70</ref>
There is overlap between the sayings of Jesus in the apocryphal texts and canonical Christian writings, and those not present in the canonical texts are called [[agrapha]]. There are at least 225 agrapha but most scholars who have studied them have drawn negative conclusions about the authenticity of most of them and see little value in using them for historical Jesus research.<ref name=vvoorst183 /> Robert Van Voorst states that the vast majority of the agrapha are certainly inauthentic.<ref name=vvoorst183 /> Scholars differ on the number of authentic agrapha, some estimating as low as seven as authentic, others as high as 18 among the more than 200, rendering them of little value altogether.<ref name=vvoorst183 >Van Voorst, Robert E (2000). ''Jesus Outside the New Testament: An Introduction to the Ancient Evidence''. Eerdmans Publishing. {{ISBN|0-8028-4368-9}} p. 183</ref> While research on apocryphal texts continues, the general scholarly opinion holds that they have little to offer to the study of the historicity of Jesus given that they are often of uncertain origin, and almost always later documents of lower value.<ref name=vvoorst215 />
==See also== * [[Christ myth theory]] * [[Census of Quirinius]], the enrollment of the Roman provinces of Syria and Judaea for tax purposes taken in the year 6/7. * [[Cultural and historical background of Jesus]] * [[Historical Jesus]] * [[Historical reliability of the Gospels]] * [[Quest for the historical Jesus]] * [[The Bible and history]]

revision.comment: /* top */clean up from page move, replaced: [[taxonomic]] → [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Species affinis''' (commonly abbreviated to: '''sp. aff.''', '''aff.''', or '''affin.''') is [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] terminology in [[zoology]] and [[botany]]. In [[open nomenclature]] it indicates that available material or evidence suggests that the proposed [[species]] is ''related to'', has an ''[[Affinity (taxonomy)|affinity]]'' to, but is ''not identical to'', the species with the [[Binomial nomenclature|binomial]] name that follows.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cactus-art.biz/note-book/Dictionary/Dictionary_S/dictionary_species_affinis.htm | title = Species affinis (Affinis) | work = Dictionary of botanic terminology | publisher = cactus-art.biz | accessdate = 2010-12-13 }}</ref> The Latin word ''affinis'' can be translated as ''closely related to'', or ''akin to''.<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Oxford Latin Dictionary |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=79 |year=1968}}</ref>
An author who inserts ''[[n.sp.]],'' or ''[[sp. nov.]], aff'' before a species name thereby states the opinion that the specimen is a new, previously [[Species description|undescribed]] species,<ref name="Bengtson 1988">{{cite web|last=Bengtson|first=P.|title=Open Nomenclature|url=http://www.palass-pubs.org/palaeontology/pdf/Vol31/Pages%20223-227.pdf|work=Palentology|accessdate=2 April 2014|year=1988|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006071437/http://www.palass-pubs.org/palaeontology/pdf/Vol31/Pages%20223-227.pdf|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref> but that there may not (yet) be enough information to complete a formal description. To use aff. alone, implies that the specimen differs suggestively from the [[holotype]] but that further progress is necessary to confirm that it is a novel species.
An example would be: a [[gastropod shell]] listed as [[Lucapina aff. aegis|''Lucapina'' aff. ''aegis'']] would mean that this shell somewhat resembles the shell of ''[[Lucapina aegis]]'', but is thought more likely to be another species, either closely related to, or closely resembling ''Lucapina aegis''. In a suitable context it also may suggest the possibility that the shell belongs to a species that has not yet been [[Species description|described]].
The use of aff. is similar to other indicators of open nomenclature such as [[cf.]], [[Species|sp.]], or ?,<ref name="Bengtson 1988"/> but the latter indicate that the species is ''uncertain'' rather than undescribed.
==See also== *[[Glossary of scientific names]] *[[List of classical abbreviations]] *[[List of Latin abbreviations]] *[[List of Latin and Greek words commonly used in systematic names]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Species Affinis}} [[Category:Species]] [[Category:Abbreviations]] [[Category:Latin words and phrases]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/195.195.56.4|195.195.56.4]] ([[User talk:195.195.56.4|talk]]) to last revision by 2600:1017:B01C:F5C3:4122:41A4:EFA2:E9C6. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Index or textual consolidation of primary and secondary sources}} {{selfref|For Wikipedia's policy on the use of tertiary sources, see [[WP:TERTIARY]].}} {{Distinguish|Tertiary sector}} A '''tertiary source''' is an index or textual consolidation of [[Primary source|primary]] and [[secondary source]]s.<ref name="umd"> [http://www.lib.umd.edu/ues/guides/primary-sources Primary, secondary and tertiary sources.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703015116/http://www.lib.umd.edu/ues/guides/primary-sources |date=2013-07-03 }}". University Libraries, University of Maryland. Retrieve 07/26/2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.odu.edu/genedinfolit/1infobasics/tertiary_information_sources.html|title=Tertiary Information Sources|date=September 2012|publisher=Old Dominion University -- ODU Libraries|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=JCU>"[http://libguides.jcu.edu.au/tertiary Tertiary sources]". James Cook University.</ref> Some tertiary sources are not to be used for academic [[research]], unless they can also be used as secondary sources, or to find other sources.<ref name=newhaven>"[http://libguides.newhaven.edu/content.php?pid=465151&sid=3809011 Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Resources]". University of New Haven.</ref>
==Overlap with secondary sources== Depending on the topic of research, a scholar may use a [[bibliography]], [[dictionary]], or [[encyclopedia]] as either a tertiary or a secondary source.<ref name="umd"> [http://www.lib.umd.edu/ues/guides/primary-sources Primary, secondary and tertiary sources.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703015116/http://www.lib.umd.edu/ues/guides/primary-sources |date=2013-07-03 }}". University Libraries, University of Maryland. Retrieve 07/26/2013</ref> This causes difficulty in defining many sources as either one type or the other.
In some [[academic discipline]]s the differentiation between a secondary and tertiary source is relative.<ref name="umd"/><ref name=JCU />
In the [[UNISIST model|United Nations International Scientific Information System (UNISIST) model]], a secondary source is a bibliography, whereas a tertiary source is a synthesis of primary sources.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Søndergaard | first1 = T. F. | last2 = Andersen | first2 = J. | last3 = Hjørland | first3 = B. | doi = 10.1108/00220410310472509 | title = Documents and the communication of scientific and scholarly information: Revising and updating the UNISIST model | journal = Journal of Documentation | volume = 59 | issue = 3 | pages = 278 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
==Types of tertiary sources== As tertiary sources, encyclopedias, [[textbook]]s, and [[compendium|compendia]] attempt to summarize, collect, and consolidate the source materials into an overview, but may also present subjective, or biased commentary and analysis (which are characteristics of secondary sources).
[[Bibliographic index|Indexes]], bibliographies, [[Concordance (publishing)|concordances]], and [[Database#Research|databases]] may not provide much textual information, but as aggregates of primary and secondary sources, they are often considered tertiary sources. So although tertiary sources are both primary and secondary, they are more towards a secondary source because of commentary and bias.
[[Almanac]]s, [[guide book|travel guides]], [[field guide]]s, and [[timeline]]s are also examples of tertiary sources.
Survey or overview articles are usually tertiary, though [[review articles]] in peer-reviewed [[academic journals]] are secondary (not be confused with film, book, etc. [[review]]s, which are primary-source opinions).
Some usually primary sources, such as [[User guide|user guides and manuals]], are secondary or tertiary (depending on the nature of the material) when written by third parties.
==See also== * [[Source text]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Sources| ]]
[[de:Sekundärliteratur#Tertiärliteratur]]

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Infobox book |name=The Crime Book |image=The Crime Book cover.jpg |caption= |author=DK Books |country=[[United States]] |language=[[English language|English]] |genre=Murder, mayhem, |publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]] |release_date=May 2, 2017 |media_type=Print [[Hardcover]], [[Ebook]] |pages=352 |isbn=978-1-4654-6286-2 |dewey= |congress= |oclc= }}
'''''The Crime Book (Big Ideas Simply Explained)''''' is a non-fiction volume co-authored by American crime writers [[Cathy Scott]], [[Shanna Hogan]], [[Rebecca Morris (author)|Rebecca Morris]], Canadian author and [[historian]] [[Lee Mellor]], and United Kingdom author Michael Kerrigan, with a foreword for the U.S. edition by Scott and the U.K. edition by crime-fiction author [[Peter James (writer)|Peter James]]. It was released by [[Dorling Kindersley|DK Books]] under its [[Big Ideas Learning]] imprint in May 2017.
==Synopsis== The publisher describes ''The Crime Book'' as a guide to criminology that explores the most infamous cases of all time, from serial killers to mob hits to war crimes and more.
It includes a variety of crimes committed by more than 100 of the world's most notorious criminals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crimetime.co.uk/mag/index.php/showarticle/4787|title=crimetime.co.uk - The Crime Book To Be Published By Dorling Kindersley|author=|date=|publisher=Crime Time News}}</ref> From [[Jack the Ripper]] to [[Jeffrey Dahmer]], the book is a study of international true-crime history that covers shocking stories through infographics and research that lays out key facts and details. It examines the science, psychology and sociology of criminal behavior. It profiles of villains, victims and detectives. Each clue is listed for readers to follow investigations from start to finish, and studies the police and detective work for each case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wgnradio.com/2017/05/02/cathy-scott-the-crime-book/|title=Cathy Scott: ‘The Crime Book’|author=|date=2 May 2017|website=wgnradio.com}}</ref>
In a Q&A article for CrimeCon's blog with Scott, the author described the crimes detailed in the book as having "such diversity that there is something for everyone. ... I can’t think of one crime that’s not represented in The Crime Book. It runs the gamut—from nonviolent cons to gangland-style criminals, to white-collar offenders—with a complete representation starting with the first known homicide committed against a Neanderthal man. Simply put, you can’t make this stuff up."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crimecon.com/blog/2017/4/9/the-crime-book-qa-with-author-cathy-scott|title=The Crime Book Q&A with Author Cathy Scott|author=|date=9 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==Critical reception==
''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine's description, in an August 2017 interview with co-author Scott about the book, wrote that it is "an encyclopedic treatment of the topic (that) makes for excellent companion reading. A compelling compilation of human trickery and awfulness, it covers crimes from arson, art forgery and kidnapping to bank robbery, drug trafficking and, of course, murder, with many of the entries accompanied by helpful illustrations."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/crime-book-what-we-learned-from-giant-history-of-true-crime-w496295|title='The Crime Book': What We Learned from Giant History of True Crime|author=Phoebe Neidl |date=August 22, 2017|publisher=''Rolling Stone''}}</ref>
''[[Reader's Digest]]'' listed it as one of its "Best New Books You Should Read This April," describing it as "everything you ever wanted to know about some of the most audacious, hideous, hilarious and mysterious acts of crime in one explosive book, filled with graphs, illustrations, quotes and timelines. This highly addictive encyclopedia of crime ... is a trivia goldmine and a helpful guide allowing you to put events into context."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readersdigest.co.uk/books/book-lists/best-new-books-you-should-read-april|title=Best new books you should read this April|author=|date=|publisher=Reader's Digest}}</ref>
''[[Culture Magazine]]'' in Germany had this to say: "The level of expertise is quite high," noting that the book "is lushly illustrated, readable and entertaining."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://culturmag.de/rubriken/buecher/bloody-chops-april-2017/100665|title=Bloody Chops - April 2017 - CulturMag|author=|date=15 April 2017|publisher=Culture Magazine}}</ref>
In its review, ''Crime Fiction Lover'' wrote that "a crack team of true-crime experts helped put it together."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crimefictionlover.com/2017/03/first-look-the-crime-book-from-dorling-kindersley/|title=First look: The Crime Book from Dorling Kindersley » CRIME FICTION LOVER|author=|date=March 2017|website=www.crimefictionlover.com}}</ref>
''Crimespree Magazine'' wrote, "The crimes covered are all over from serial killers to gangsters and outlaws to kidnappers and elderly Brit bank robbers. This is a great book."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crimespreemag.com/trio-non-fiction-crime-books/|title=A Trio Of Great Non-Fiction Crime Books|author=|date=12 April 2017|publisher=Crimespree Magazine}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/553804/the-crime-book-by-dk/9781465462862/ Publisher's ''The Crime Book'' page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Crime Book}}

page.title: The Rough Guide to True Crime

revision.comment: added [[Category:Reference works]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = The Rough Guide to True Crime | title_orig = | translator = | image = Rough Guide to True Crime cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Cathy Scott]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States, United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[True crime]], [[Reference]] | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | release_date = August 2009 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages =336 pp | isbn = 978-1858283852 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Rough Guide to True Crime''''' is a non-fiction paperback reference guide to national and international true crime cases by American [[True crime|crime writer]] [[Cathy Scott]]. It was released in the UK and US in August 2009 by [[Penguin Books]] through its [[Rough Guides]] imprint.
== Summary == ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' is a compilation of a variety of cases, including historic crimes, with sections broken down by the type of offenses and who committed them. It includes black-and-white photos as illustration. Psychological profiles are included throughout by forensic expert Dr. Louis B. Schlesinger, who explains the psychology of serial killers, murderers, hit men and burglars.<ref>[http://www.waterstones.com/waterstonesweb/products/Cathy-Scott/The-Rough-Guide-to-True-Crime/6708060/ True crime Reviews: ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' (Book) by Cathy Scott (2009): reviews.waterstones.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The book features [[serial killer]] [[Jeffrey Dahmer]], mob hitman [[Richard Kuklinski|Richard "The Iceman" Kuklinski]], [[John Wayne Glover]] "The Granny Killer," and British "Doctor of Death" [[Harold Shipman]].
Scott's story from ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' about mob enforcer [[Herbert Blitzstein]] was selected for inclusion in the July 2012 retrospective of crime writing, ''[[Masters of True Crime|Masters of True Crime: Chilling Stories of Murder and the Macabre]]''.<ref>[http://www.thebigthrill.org/2012/07/masters-of-true-crime-by-r-barri-flowers-editor/ ''The Big Thrill'' magazine, "Masters of True Crime by R. Barri Flowers (Editor)"<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The author appeared on [[BlogTalkRadio]]'s "True Murder" show and described some of the crimes included in the book that were committed in the 19th century as "a different time in America, where people like [[Billy the Kid]] could walk in and just rob a bank" and get away with it. And while "there was nothing glamorous about what they did, they are a part of lore."<ref>[http://www.blogtalkradio.com/dan-zupansky1/2010/01/28/true-murder-episode-1-diane-fanning-baby-be-mine True Murder-Episode 3-Cathy Scott; ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' 01/27 by True Murder | Blog Talk Radio<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Critical reception == The book was featured at [[BookExpo America]] 2009's trade fair in [[Dorling Kindersley|DK Publishing]]'s booth in New York City.<ref>[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/trade-shows-events/article/14565-bookexpo-america-2009-around-the-bea-booths-c-d.html ''Publishers Weekly'': BookExpo America 2009: Around the BEA Booths: C - D<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In a review, ''[[True Crime Zine|True Crime Book Reviews]]'' wrote, "From the Moors murders and Harold Shipman, to the murder of 2pac, this guide illuminates the psychology in play behind the most intriguing crimes in history, from the absurd to the appalling. ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' explores the best of the haunting genre of True Crime."<ref>[http://truecrimebookreviews.blogspot.com/2009/05/new-true-crime-books-august-2009.html ''True Crime Book Reviews'': New True Crime Books August 2009<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Contents == *Outlaws: "The money, or your life" *Heists and Robberies *Kidnapped *White-collar Crime *Deception: The Art of the Con *Homicide *Serial Killers *Organized Crime *Dirty Cops and Bad Apples *Lesser Violations *Cybercrime
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.worldcat.org/title/rough-guide-to-true-crime/oclc/246886342&referer=brief_results ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' in libraries (WorldCat catalog)] * [http://www.roughguides.com/shop/rough-guide-true-crime/ebook/ Penguin's ''Rough Guide to True Crime'' book page] * [http://womenincrimeink.blogspot.com/2011/03/los-angeles-street-gangs-bloods-crips.html Book excerpt, "Los Angeles Street Gangs: Bloods & Crips"] * [https://www.amazon.com/Rough-Guide-True-Crime-Reference/dp/185828385X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1371709968&sr=1-1&keywords=the+rough+guide+to+true+crime Amazon's book page]

revision.text:
A '''three-letter acronym''' ('''TLA'''), or '''three-letter abbreviation''', is an [[abbreviation]], specifically an [[Acronym|acronym, alphabetism, or initialism]], consisting of three letters. These are usually the initial letters of the words of the phrase abbreviated, and are written in capital letters (upper case); three-letter abbreviations such as ''etc.'' and ''Mrs.'' are not three-letter acronyms, but "TLA" {{em|itself}} is a TLA (an example of an [[Autological word|autological]] abbreviation).
Most three-letter abbreviations are ''initialisms'': all the letters are pronounced as the names of letters, as in ''[[Acolytes Protection Agency|APA]]'' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|eɪ|p|iː|ˈ|eɪ}} {{respell|AY|pee|AY|'}}. Some are acronyms pronounced as a word; [[computed axial tomography]], CAT, is almost always pronounced as the animal's name in "CAT scan".
==Examples== <!-- Editors' note: Comprehensive lists of TLAs can be found at [[:Category:Wikipedia lists of TLAs]]. The following is a list of ILLUSTRATIVE examples. By all means add new categories and illustrative examples of those new categories. **************************************************************************************************************************** However ***** PLEASE DO NOT ADD ENDLESS LISTS OF EXAMPLES – THEY ARE ALREADY COVERED BY [[:Category:Wikipedia lists of TLAs]]. ***** **************************************************************************************************************************** --> * Countries: '''[[Central African Republic|CAR]]''', '''[[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]''', and '''[[United States|USA]]''' * American Presidents: '''[[Franklin D. Roosevelt|FDR]]''', '''[[John F. Kennedy|JFK]]''', and '''[[Lyndon Baines Johnson|LBJ]]''' * Computer phrases: '''[[Central processing unit|CPU]]''', '''[[DOS]]''', '''[[Random-access memory|RAM]]''', '''[[Read-only memory|ROM]]''', and '''[[GNU]]''' * File extensions: '''[[.jpg|JPG]]''', and '''[[Microsoft_Excel#File_formats|XLS]]''' * Corporations: '''[[AMD]]''', '''[[IBM]]''', and '''[[NEC]]''' * Currency: '''[[USD]]''', '''[[GBP]]''', and '''[[Swiss Franc|CHF]]''' * Business: '''[[Chief executive officer|CEO]]''', '''[[Chief financial officer|CFO]]''' and other [[Corporate title|C-level]] officers * '''T'''hree '''L'''etter '''A'''gencies: '''[[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]''', '''[[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]''', '''[[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]]''', '''[[Federal Security Service (Russia)|FSB]]''', and '''[[National Security Agency|NSA]]''' * [[Television network]]s: '''ABC''' ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|Aus.]], [[American Broadcasting Company|U.S.]]), '''[[BBC]]''' (UK), '''CBC''' ([[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|Canada]], [[Chubu-Nippon Broadcasting|Japan]]), and '''[[NHK]]''' (Japan) * [[Personal advertisement]]s: '''SBM''' for Single Black Male, '''STR''' for Short Term Relationship * Chemistry, biology, pharmaceuticals: '''[[Genetically modified organism|GMO]]''', '''[[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]]''' and '''[[Monosodium glutamate|MSG]]''' * Religion: '''[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS]]''' * Clinical medicine: '''[[coronary artery disease|CAD]]''' and '''[[heart failure|CHF]]''' * Communications shorthand: '''[[LOL]]''' and '''[[SMS language#Common acronyms|OMG]]''' * Military and weaponry: '''[[wiktionary:Appendix:Military slang#B|BFR]]''' and '''[[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]]''' * Wars and political conflicts: '''[[Hundred Years' War|HYW]]''' and '''[[World War I|WWI]]''' * [[ISO currency codes]]: '''[[Pound sterling|GBP]]''', '''[[Japanese yen|JPY]]''' and '''[[United States dollar|USD]]''' * [[List of airports by IATA code|IATA airport codes]]: '''[[Los Angeles International Airport|LAX]]''' and '''[[London Heathrow Airport|LHR]]''' * Academic testing: '''[[ACT (test)|ACT]]''', '''[[SAT]]''' * Canine registries: '''[[American Kennel Club|AKC]]''' and '''[[Canadian Kennel Club|CKC]]''' * Sports organizations: '''[[National Football League|NFL]]''', '''[[Major League Baseball|MLB]]''', (North America); '''[[Australian Football League|AFL]]''' and '''[[National Rugby League|NRL]]''' (Australia); '''[[Nippon Professional Baseball|NPB]]''' (Japan); '''[[Liga ACB|ACB]]''', '''[[Liga de Fútbol Profesional|LFP]]''' (Spain); '''[[Indian Premier League|IPL]]''' (India), EPL (England), '''[[World Boxing Organization|WBO]]''' (Puerto Rico) *[[Ship prefix]]es: '''[[Her Majesty's Ship|HMS]]''', '''[[United States Ship|USS]]''' and '''[[Royal Mail Ship|RMS]]''' * State [[Australian postal abbreviations|postal abbreviations]]: '''[[NSW]]''', '''[[QLD]]''', '''[[Victoria (Australia)|VIC]]''' and '''[[Tasmania|TAS]]''' (Australia)
==History and origins==
The exact phrase ''three-letter acronym'' appeared in the sociology literature in 1975.<ref name=Levy>{{cite journal |first=M. J. |last=Levy |title=Review of ''The Logic of Social Systems'' |journal=[[American Journal of Sociology]] |volume=81 |issue=3 |year=1975 |jstor=2777655 |doi=10.1086/226119 |page=658 |quote=The acronyms DSE and DNA have something in common: each is a three-letter acronym.}}</ref> Three-letter acronyms were used as [[mnemonic]]s in biological sciences, from 1977<ref name=Seavey>{{cite journal |first=S. R. |last=Seavey |first2=P. H. |last2=Raven |year=1977 |title=Chromosomal Differentiation and the Sources of the South American Species of ''Epilobium'' (Onagraceae) |journal=Journal of Biogeography |volume=4 |issue=1 |page=57 | doi = 10.2307/3038128 |jstor=3038128 |quote=All taxa indicated by three-letter acronyms with strains indicated by a fourth letter if necessary.}}</ref> and their practical advantage was promoted by Weber in 1982.<ref>{{cite journal |first=W. A. |last=Weber |year=1982 |title=Mnemonic Three-Letter Acronyms for the Families of Vascular Plants: A Device for More Effective Herbarium Curation |journal=Taxon |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=74–88 |jstor=1220592 |doi=10.2307/1220592}}</ref> They are used in many other fields, but the term TLA is particularly associated with computing.<ref>{{cite journal |first=K. D. |last=Nilsen |first2=A. P. |last2=Nilsen |year=1995 |title=Literary Metaphors and Other Linguistic Innovations in Computer Language |journal=The English Journal |volume=84 |issue=6 |pages=65–71 |jstor=820897 }}</ref> In 1980, the manual for the Sinclair [[ZX81]] home computer used and explained TLA.<ref name=ZX81>[[Steve Vickers (academia)|Steven Vickers]] ''ZX81 Basic Programming'', Sinclair Research Limited, page 161 "As you can see, everything has a three letter abbreviation (TLA)."</ref> The specific generation of three-letter acronyms in computing was mentioned in a [[JPL]] report of 1982.<ref name=JPL>[http://tmo.jpl.nasa.gov/progress_report/42-70/70R.PDF TDA Progress Report] R. Hull (1982) An Introduction to the new Productivity Information Management System page 176</ref> In 1988, in a paper titled "On the cruelty of really teaching computer science", eminent computer scientist [[Edsger W. Dijkstra]] wrote <!-- disparagingly (see quote in context) --> "Because no endeavour is respectable these days without a TLA ..."<ref>[http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~EWD/transcriptions/EWD10xx/EWD1036.html On the cruelty of really teaching computer science]</ref> By 1992 it was in a [[Microsoft]] handbook.<ref>Dan Gookin (1992) ''The Microsoft Guide to Optimizing Windows'' page 211</ref>
==Combinatorics==
The number of possible three-letter abbreviations (or [[permutations]]) using the 26 letters of the alphabet from A to Z (AAA, AAB ... to ZZY, ZZZ) is 26 × 26 × 26 = 17,576. Another 26 × 26 × 10 = 6760 can be produced if the third element is allowed to be a digit 0-9, giving a total of 24,336.
In [[English language|English]], [[WWW (disambiguation)|WWW]] is the longest possible TLA to [[Pronunciation of "www"|pronounce]], typically requiring nine [[syllable]]s. The usefulness of TLAs typically comes from how it is quicker to say the [[acronym]] instead of than the phrase they represent, however saying 'WWW' in English requires three times as many syllables than the phrase it is meant to abbreviate (World Wide Web). Consequently, "www" is sometimes abbreviated as "dubdubdub" in speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bulletin.brynmawr.edu/features/digispeak-a-glossary-of-the-new-lingo/|title=DigiSpeak: A Glossary of the New Lingo|date=May 2011|website=bryn mawr alumnae bulletin|publisher=Bryn Mawr College Alumnae Association|accessdate=August 14, 2016}}</ref>
==References in popular culture== {{refimprove section|date=October 2015}} * As early as 1967, the musical [[Hair (musical)|Hair]] included the song "Initials", whose final verse consisted only of TLAs, viz: "LBJ IRT USA LSD. LSD LBJ FBI CIA. FBI CIA LSD LBJ." * In 1986, Will Shatter of the band [[Flipper (band)|Flipper]] formed a band named "Any Three Initials" (A3I), as a parody of the preponderance of hardcore punk bands with three-initial names. * In 1998, the [[UK|British]] band [[Love and Rockets (band)|Love and Rockets]] released their last album, [[Lift (Love and Rockets album)|Lift]], featuring the song "R.I.P. 20 C." that, apart from the refrain, consists only of three-letter abbreviations. A contest was held rewarding the first person to correctly give the meanings of all 69 of them. * In 1999, German hip-hop group [[Die Fantastischen Vier]] (The Fantastic Four) released the song "MfG" ("Mit freundlichen Grüßen", [[german language|German]] for "Best regards", literally "With friendly greetings"), also mainly consisting of TLAs.<ref>[https://genius.com/Die-fantastischen-vier-mit-freundlichen-gruen-mfg-lyrics Lyrics of "MfG"]</ref> * In 1999, the author [[Douglas Adams]] remarked: "The World Wide Web is the only thing I know of whose shortened form takes three times longer to say than what it's short for."<ref>Douglas Adams, The Independent on Sunday, 1999</ref> * In 2001, Portland Oregon songwriter [[Craig Carothers]] produced a song entitled "BFD" which includes many three-letter acronyms throughout the [[lyrics]]. It has been recorded by Carothers as well as [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Berkley Hart]] and [[Don Henry]]. * According to the [[Jargon File]], a journalist once asked hacker [[Paul Boutin (journalist)|Paul Boutin]] what he thought the biggest problem in computing in the 1990s would be. Paul's straight-faced response was: "There are only 17,000 three-letter acronyms." * The [[Jargon File]] also mentions the abbreviation "ETLA" for "extended three-letter acronym" to refer to four-letter acronyms/abbreviations. "Extended three-letter acronym" is sometimes abbreviated to "XTLA".
==See also== {{wiktionary|TLA}} * [[ISO 4217]] (currency code) * [[List of acronyms]] * [[List of airports by IATA code]] * [[List of all two-letter combinations]] * [[List of computing and IT abbreviations]] * [[List of IOC country codes]] * [[List of three-letter broadcast callsigns in the United States]] * [[Photographers' abbreviations]] * [[Q code]] * [[RAS syndrome]] * [[Acronym]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Three-letter Acronym}} [[Category:Abbreviations]] [[Category:Acronyms| T]]

revision.comment: /* Life */ Link to [[Richard Chaffers]]
revision.text:
'''William Chaffers''' (28 September 1811 – 12 April 1892) was an English antiquary and writer of reference works on [[hallmark]]s, and marks on [[ceramics]]. His ''Marks and Monograms on Pottery and Porcelain'', first published in 1863, has appeared in many later editions.
==Life== Chaffers was the son of William Chaffers and wife Sarah, and was born in Watling Street, London, in 1811; he was descended from a brother of [[Richard Chaffers]] (1731–1765), a manufacturer of [[Liverpool porcelain]]. He was educated at Margate and at [[Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood|Merchant Taylors' School]], where he was entered in 1824.<ref name=dnbsupp>{{cite DNBSupp|first=Thomas|last=Seccombe|authorlink=Thomas Seccombe|wstitle=Chaffers, William|volume=1|page=409}}</ref><ref name=odnb>{{cite ODNB|id=5016|title=Chaffers, William}}</ref>
He was attracted to antiquarian studies while a clerk in the city of London, by the discovery of Roman and medieval antiquities in the foundations of the [[Royal Exchange, London|Royal Exchange]] during 1838–9. At the same time he began to concentrate attention upon the study of gold and silver plate and ceramics, especially in regard to the official and other marks by which dates and places of fabrication can be distinguished. In 1863 Chaffers published two important works:<ref name=dnbsupp/> * ''Hall Marks on Gold and Silver Plate, illustrated, with Tables of Annual Date Letters employed in the Assay Offices of the United Kingdom''; in the 8th edition of 1896 it included "Histories of the Goldsmiths' Trade, both in England and France, and revised London and Provincial Tables", and an introductory essay by C. A. Markham.<ref name=dnbsupp/> * ''Marks and Monograms on Pottery and Porcelain of the Renaissance and Modern Periods, with Historical Notices of each Manufactory, preceded by an introductory Essay on Vasa Fictilia of the Greek, Romano-British, and Mediæval Eras''. The aim of the work was to be for ceramics what {{ill|Franz Brulliot|de}}'s ''Dictionnaire des Monogrammes'' was to painting, and it at once established Chaffers as the leading authority upon his subject.<ref name=dnbsupp/> Many subsequent editions have appeared, revised by later editors; the 9th edition appeared in 1900, and the 15th edition in 1965.<ref name=odnb/>
Other publications are ''The Keramic Gallery'', in 2 volumes, with 500 illustrations (1872); a handbook abridged from ''Marks and Monograms'' (1874); ''Gilda Aurifabrorum'', a history of goldsmiths and plate workers and their marks (1883); also a priced catalogue of coins, and other minor catalogues.<ref name=dnbsupp/><ref name=odnb/>
His reputation was furthered in organizing exhibitions of art treasures, at [[Art Treasures Exhibition, Manchester 1857|Manchester in 1857]], [[1862 International Exhibition|South Kensington in 1862]], Leeds in 1869, Dublin in 1872, Wrexham in 1876, and Hanley (at the great Staffordshire exhibition of ceramics) in 1890. Chaffers was elected [[Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London]] in 1843, and he was a frequent contributor to ''Archæologia'', to ''[[Notes and Queries]]'', and to various learned periodicals upon the two subjects of which he had particular knowledge.<ref name=dnbsupp/>
In 1841 he married Charlotte Matilda, daughter of John Hewett.<ref name=odnb/> About 1870 he retired from [[Fitzroy Square]] to a house in Willesden Lane, and later moved to [[West Hampstead]], where he died on 12 April 1892.<ref name=dnbsupp/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
